Award.AwardTitle: Development of high power laser components and in situ contamination monitoring for future terrestrial GW detectors
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research award will enable investigations important to the Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (Advanced LIGO). First, the quality of the mirror surfaces is crucial to the performance of Advanced LIGO. A method will be developed which can monitor mirror surface contaminants during the operation of Advanced LIGO using a nonlinear
optical technique known as surface second harmonic generation. Second, optical isolation of high power laser beams is important for Advanced LIGO, and this research will address issues with the development of optical isolators capable of handling higher laser powers.

Advanced LIGO will open a new astronomical window --- the ability to probe some of the most cataclysmic events in universe through the emission of gravitational waves, a mechanism proposed by Albert Einstein almost 100 years ago, but yet to be directly observed. These investigations will both aid in the operation of Advanced LIGO over long time scales and potentially improve its performance once it is in operation. They will also impact many applications which use high power lasers. Finally, this research will also foster international collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had two main thrusts. The first was the development of robust Faraday isolators capable of handling kilowatt average power lasers. This research is a continuation of developments that led to the Faraday isolators used in Advanced LIGO.  The second thrust was the development of methods for characterizing and identifying specific damage and contaminants on mirrors in optical cavities with high circulating power.

 

Current state-of-the-art of high power Faraday isolators  are limited to operating powers of several hundreds watts at most. We have performed investigations to extend Faraday isolator operation to multi-kilowatt power range.  A number of different techniques were employed: passive compensation of thermally induced effects, shorter magneto-optic elements in combination with higher magnetic fields, and the use of lower absorption magneto- optic elements. These allowed a Faraday isolator providing high isolation ratio (30 dB) at average laser powers of 700 W to be constructed. In addition, a high-power Faraday isolater utilizing thermo-electric cooling of the magneto-optic element via the Peltier effect has been developed and tested. Thermal stabilization of magneto-optical elements ensures reliable operation of the device at incident power up to 1.5 kW.

 

Silicon carbide (SiC) baffles and beam dumps are widely used in the advanced LIGO design An experiment was conducted to examine the effects of high power laser beams on SiC, using a 70 W infrared laser and a high vacuum environment. The damage threshold of SiC was measured when exposed to intense radiation as well as the temperature rise and outgassing rate of SiC at  irradiances just below and also well above the damage threshold. Outgassing was dominated by water vapor and Si or N2.

 

We  also conducted a theoretical investigation of surface second harmonic generation processes from the interface of two dielectric surfaces. Parameters of the laser excitation beam (peak power, repetition rate, spot size, angle of incidence, polarization) were optimized for the application of the detection of contamination on mirrors in high-performance optical cavities. The calculations included the required laser parameters (energy, pulse duration, and spot size) and detection parameters (photomultiplier tubes, CCDs). The signal is quadratically proportional to intensity of the laser radiation and linear proportional to pulse length and beam diameter and also strongly depends on the reflectivity of laser beam from the surface and on the beam incident angle. We found that it is necessary to use femtosecond lasers for surface second harmonic generation from dielectric surfaces to prevent surface damage. We conducted an experimental investigation of the power scaling of the signal on dielectric mirrors, both clean and contaminated. A significant increase of the signal was observed in all cases of contamination, clearly distinguishable from the clean surface.

 

David Reitze worked with musician/composer Andrea Centazzo to organize a public lecture and concert at the University of Florida in November 2009. Reitze gave a ½-hour lecture on the nature of gravity and gravitational waves, followed by a 1 1/2 hour multi-media concert “Einstein’s Messengers” by Andrea Centazzo. Approximately 225 people were in attendance.
